step_by_step_thinking: The patient presents with acne, hirsutism, obesity, menstrual irregularity (45-day cycle), and elevated glucose levels (160 mg/dL 2-hour glucose). These symptoms align with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), which is characterized by hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne), insulin resistance (elevated glucose, obesity), and menstrual irregularities. PCOS is also associated with obesity and a family history of diabetes. Hypothyroidism may cause weight gain and menstrual issues but does not typically explain insulin resistance or hirsutism. Idiopathic hirsutism lacks the metabolic and menstrual abnormalities seen here. Ovarian hyperthecosis is rare and usually presents with more severe virilization, which is not described. The combination of symptoms and lab findings strongly supports PCOS.
